title: Riot seems to boast their champion roster like they're all playable.
body:
Is it just me that finds this irritating? You have riot sneaking in mentions about how big their champion roster is like it's supposed to be impressive when so many of them are just unplayable. You have champions that Riot hasn't touched in ages that need everything from minor tweaks (Mana rebalancing on Anivia, for instance) to champions that they touch of death (Elise change.) when they're supposedly trying to help. And then you have the forgotten champions that are simply out dated or Riot has promised an update Soon(TM) that have been lost to the sands of time without a single word about it like that Fiora update that Guinsoo was working on.

Does anyone else get this feeling or am I in the minority?

replies.body:
lack of diversity at a pro level comes largely from pro players practicing the same champions and team playstyle over and over and only feeling comfortable with a small champion pool as a result.

the amount of practice it takes to work that cohesively as a 5 man squad is pretty ridiculous.  this is why you can look at TiP and say "they play sivir/alistar based aggressive comps" and you can look at TSM and say "they play to lategame teamfighting centered around Bjergsen."  It's because these are the playstyles that those teams are comfortable bringing when actual money is on the table.  It's because they practice it day in and day out and they would be crazy to just throw caution to the wind and try something new for no reason.  A jack of all trades is a master of none.

> [{quoted}](name=Nasreth,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-06-30T02:05:56.259+0000)
>
> lack of diversity at a pro level comes largely from pro players practicing the same champions and team playstyle over and over and only feeling comfortable with a small champion pool as a result.
> 
> the amount of practice it takes to work that cohesively as a 5 man squad is pretty ridiculous.  this is why you can look at TiP and say "they play sivir/alistar based aggressive comps" and you can look at TSM and say "they play to lategame teamfighting centered around Bjergsen."  It's because these are the playstyles that those teams are comfortable bringing when actual money is on the table.  It's because they practice it day in and day out and they would be crazy to just throw caution to the wind and try something new for no reason.  A jack of all trades is a master of none.

That would be a better argument if in fact teams did stick to certain champs that they're known for, but that isn't the case.  Every team switches to play the exact same champs that are currently the most powerful.  Nobody practiced Ekko over and over, they didn't have time to.  Yet he made it into every team's lineup based on sheer statistical strength.  

It really just a consequence of the decisions the balance team has made and the pigeonholing that they've done to ensure every game progresses the exact same way, using the exact same strategies, and the exact same characters.  It doesn't need to be that way at all, that's simply how they've chosen to make it.

>Nobody practiced Ekko over and over, they didn't have time to. Yet he made it into every team's lineup based on sheer statistical strength

I believe that can largely be attributed to a few things.  Firstly is that with him being so new, no one had time to practice against him and learn counters.  The second yes being that he was released a bit overpowered and needed a few love taps.  The third being the hype around him, with so many people talking about how OP he was, he brought a lot of intimidation factor to the table.
You should have just said, "overpowered."  Pros pick the strong champions.  It doesn't take them long to learn a champion well enough to be comfortable.

this is half of it - the other half is that Pros pick champions that are successful. Yes, everyone knew Ekko, Gnar, and Rek Sai were strong on release, and the pros picked them up immediately. 

But what about AP Kogmaw? Mid Varus? Urgot? Viktor? AD Fizz? Heacrim top? These champions were played by one or two players and were successful. At one point or another, all these picks were considered troll, but are now meta. This is because one pro player found success with it, and the others learned that champion as well - partially due to the fact that if you can pick that champion, you dont need to waste a ban on it. Top Nautilus is becoming popular in Asia for this exact reason. Its hard to say that these champions are OP - they have glaring weaknesses that can be exploited. 

And then there are champions that players tried, but only few found success on - things like Shy's Shyvana or Reignover's Olaf. These champions have low banrates, but are still targeted bans against certain teams. Not because they are overpowered, but because they are sucessful.

In Varus cases, the 5.5 change to make his Q cooldown begin on first cast is what was needed to really make caster Varus viable in the mid lane, since it helps tear builds stack more overall.

Patch 5.5 also fixed a Viktor bug where the Death Ray detonation upgrade would cancel his auto-attacks, meaning he became more playable by virtue of a bug fix.

Urgot got his buff that makes his shield scale off his mana, making his tear build much more powerful overall.

All these champions that are "suddenly" seeing professional play are either as a result of recent buffs or in response to those buffs. Strictly speaking, none of these champions are simply being played out of the blue. They're played outside of professional play to determine viability, and brought in if they are seen as a stronger, overall better pick.

But who brings them in? Its always one person who starts the trend, others see it as being strong, then they copy it. 

I mean, nobody in the LCS touched Ryze this season until they saw Huni chain-snare, though it was very much possible for many patches his rework - you can say it was because Ryze got buffed, but these guys arent even maxing his Q and he was still chain snaring well past healthy gameplay after level 6. You cant tell me that a stronger shield catapulted Urgot into a top tier pick at both Mid and Bot when he was nothing but troll before. Or that a Mage was buffed to the point of OP by fixing an autoattack bug. 

If Viktor wasnt played in the pros, people would say he is horrible since he has low range, low mobility, and very conditional CC. He also gets the double-edged sword of having a strong early damage item for free, but cant build the full AP itemization for the right balance of Damage, CDR, and actives/passives.

"one person starts the trend" really feels like a logical fallacy. I sincerely doubt that only ONE person decided to test out mid-caster Varus to incorporate into a team comp, it's just that one person finished figuring out how to make it work for their team before anyone else.

Ryze became a pick/ban in the LCS the second his passive got buffed to last 6 seconds at all ultimate ranks, meaning that he could chain-snare longer at earlier ranks than with the 5.8 iteration of his re-work. I mean, let's be honest, adding an entire 3 seconds of chain-snaring early game was the breaking point that pushed him. His Rune Prison already had a WAY harder scaling, and was outright better at Rank 3 in 5.8 than it is now.

And I'm not saying that these buffs made them op, but it gave them something to be viable for, at the very least a niche. No one plays Urgot or Varus every game, but they play them in composition that they fit in, and as counter-picks, rather than as out-right picks overall.

As for Viktor, it helps that other low mobility mages like Kog'Maw, Varus, and Cass came back into competitive play. His high burst combo makes his trades nice and his CC, while unreliable, is good as a zoning tool in teamfights.

i admit - im talking about specific champions that shot up in popularity, not the ones that are overall strong. The picks that werent even popular in soloqueue, but happened to do amazing in the pros. 

things like Support Veigar (prerework). Most likely it wasnt even the pro who started the trend; they probably saw someone in soloque do amazing then copied the playstyle. But being completely honest about the community, the pros determine what is Meta. It takes one professional player guy who does well to make support Veigar viable when previously it was just troll.

> That would be a better argument if in fact teams did stick to certain champs that they're known for, but that isn't the case. Every team switches to play the exact same champs that are currently the most powerful.

I can't stress enough just how true this statement is.

Excuse me if I use Sona as an example here.  Currently there are multiple support players in professional play that are well-known for maining her in seasons 2 and 3, but have barely looked at her since the nerfs in patch 3.14 where Nami came out less for wear and Lulu was practically buffed, perhaps the only support that actually saw that patch as a buff.  Move ahead to July of season 4 and Sona was as a matter-of-fact the 2nd most played support in high Elo.  The moment patch 4.13 went live on the 30th, her pick-rate disappeared, her win-rate in pro-play fell to 0% and has still yet to rise above that and the average rank of her mains fell over 4 whole divisions.

> [{quoted}](name=Nasreth,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-06-30T02:05:56.259+0000)
>

>  A jack of all trades is a master of none.

That must be why {{champion:412}} {{champion:64}} {{champion:421}} {{champion:31}} {{champion:245}} {{champion:79}} are considered completely unviable in LCS.

Oh wait.

Almost all of the champs are viable.

There are no more than I would say 5 who are so bad that you should never pick them ever.

> [{quoted}](name=Lane Cancer,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=000b,timestamp=2015-06-30T04:20:34.018+0000)
>
> Almost all of the champs are viable.
> 
> There are no more than I would say 5 who are so bad that you should never pick them ever.

Viable means able to be picked in a competitive game. If a champion is not best in class or at least best at what they do, there is no reason to pick them. You may not auto lose if you pick Fiora or Syndra etc, but there is always another champion that is better, which means you should always pick that other champion if you're playing to win, therefore she is not viable.

Every champion capable of winning games is **viable**.
You're talking about **optimal**.
It's not the same, every champion is viable, yet there are a few optimal champions that are played in competitive games. Pro players earn money when they win games, so of course they will always pick the best possible champion (or the safest one, harder to counter).
Also, competitive =/= solo queue. For most players, Fiora is probably one of the best champions they could pick if they wanted to carry a solo queue game.
The champions with the highest win-rate are Amumu, Malzahar, Diana, Janna, Heimerdinger and Wukong, most of them are not competitive picks, yet they have been at the top of the solo-queue win-rate for months. You just called those champions "unviable".

Viable means "capable of success", remember that.

> [{quoted}](name=Tsohgder,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=000b00000001,timestamp=2015-06-30T07:08:42.585+0000)
>
> Every champion capable of winning games is **viable**.

By this logic intentional feeding is viable.

So either that's not the way the term "viable" is used,or everyone using "everything is viable" in that sense is a complete moron.

> [{quoted}](name=Tsohgder,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=000b00000001,timestamp=2015-06-30T07:08:42.585+0000)
>
> Every champion capable of winning games is **viable**.
> You're talking about **optimal**.
> It's not the same, every champion is viable, yet there are a few optimal champions that are played in competitive games.

It is the same though. In a competitive game mode, only the optimal picks are viable.
The only reason udyr players suck is because they try and go full trick2g D GATES 1v5 and get killed because they have no clue how udyr works. Udyr himself is pretty good.

Sona's sole strength in the entire game is in a pre-laning 5-man invade comp.  This current kit's power peak is pre-laning full-team teamfighting.  The moment laning begins, her strength immediately begins rapidly declining for the rest of the game, falling off harder in the first 10 minutes than a Lee Sin at 60 minutes.

The only way she can retain the slightest bit of relevancy is through artificial scaling and max CDR for optimizing Spellblade and Echo procs, but even this is a vane attempt.  The exact same items can be built by any champion in the game and every last one of them would utilize them more effectively.

They're viable when there is new item change.

{{champion:19}} was useless, then with Devourer in 5.0, he was everywhere and even had to get nerfed.
{{champion:79}} was considered trash post-reworked, couple patches later, with zero buff or nerf, he now has 80% ban rate due to Cinderhulk.

Wrong. WW pre-devourer was here & strong. 
After devourer he and item got nerfed leaving him in gray zone of crap champions.

AP gragas was great but he took a lot more skill than cinderhulk so people didn't bother to learn.
Playing him with the cinderhulk is really easy... All you have to worry about is not messing up the ult too badly.

If a champ hasn't been touched in ages, they're either upcoming for a rework, or they're pretty fine. Jokes about Anivia being manaless aside, she NEEDS to be heavily gated because of how much her kit offers. It's comparable to some of the champions released today. Elise is also a touchy zone. She has to be buffed slowly, because otherwise, we get the terror she was back in s2. And the Fiora rework was lowered on the priority scaling, since there are others that need it more (Poppy, GP, WW, etc.)
That's false. Riot has nerfed mana regen for every champion. She used to be fine with old mana regen system. Riot just didn't adress that currectly some champions are in bad spot.

> [{quoted}](name=Saianna,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=00050000,timestamp=2015-06-30T04:16:46.249+0000)
>
> That's false. Riot has nerfed mana regen for every champion. She used to be fine with old mana regen system. Riot just didn't adress that currectly some champions are in bad spot.

That reveals a big issue I have with Riot actually, they're nerfed to the ground in the current meta and when it shifts Riot doesn't bother revisiting them. Stuff like Elise in purgatory for quite a long time, and when was the last time Riot talked about characters like Taric?
They talked about Taric very recently... they said his rework + VU is 95% finished and that it's coming during the winter.
6 more months for 5% of the rework?
Anivia has always needed two mana items she still needs two mana items seems pretty neutral to me.

> [{quoted}](name=Sammystorm,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=000500000001,timestamp=2015-06-30T08:15:15.734+0000)
>
> Anivia has always needed two mana items she still needs two mana items seems pretty neutral to me.

I've played her a bit and noticed some oddities, mainly why can't she ult while in zhonyas and why does it get canceled by cc? It seems to be close to the category of Swain's ultimate (A channel, but not in a traditional sense) which works through both. Mana tweaks were just the first thing that came to mind. ~~Also i think they removed eggnivia so thats absolutely terrible. ~~
She has the only toggle that is canceled by cc.

I don't even get why Fiora would need a rework. She's pretty viable in SoloQ. And don't tell me she's too easy to counter in high Elo, there are people in Master/Challenger Tier who even play Teemo successfully.

> [{quoted}](name=Remikaze,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=00050001,timestamp=2015-06-30T07:16:15.129+0000)
>
> I don't even get why Fiora would need a rework. She's pretty viable in SoloQ. And don't tell me she's too easy to counter in high Elo, there are people in Master/Challenger Tier who even play Teemo successfully.

I believe the reasoning behind the rework is that not only does it not particularly fit the theme of "Extremely precise and skilled fencer" but it's also way too simple and a tad bit bland in terms of things you can do.
"#LCSBIGPLAYS" above all

>(Mana rebalancing on Anivia)

Every time someone references anivia as needing any buffs whatsoever it invalidates anything they have to say for the rest of the post

aren't you referencing post about anivia buffs?

So does it means that your post is invalid?
All of the champs are playable.
{{champion:122}}

> [{quoted}](name=Mat7itan,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2015-06-30T02:26:37.835+0000)
>
> All of the champs are playable.

Viable perhaps would have been the better word choice, however nitpicking kinda takes away from the main argument I'm attempting to make here. My point still stands.

Yeah, and Riot likes to push how their matchmaking is 'fair' in the new player guide on their own website yet the game is riddled with smurf accounts that absolutely destroy the new player experience but Riot won't do anything about it since they don't consider smurfing a problem.

well, some of the minority champs are actually pretty strong in certain cases, but fall off in others, so it makes it difficult to make them the new "overpowered or nothing" meta

for instance, I started playing mordekaiser again because he's really fun and manaless with the ability to duel melee specialized champs and beat any mage down

some champs take a lot of itemization to make a playstyle, like critikayle.  she's normally an attack speed or AP champ, but she can build critical and play like an adc with her ult and her innate stats, same with poppy and other unused champs


it's the champs that riot pays attention to that are fairly toxic, such as Zed...virtually untouched since release yet one of the most toxic kits there is(though he has a really high skill floor(for those of you who call it that))

then there are champs like jinx, blitzcrank, and thresh.  jinx has her own crowd control in two forms and a move speed/other stats steroids whereas blitzcrank and thresh can lock down early game assured

Nautilus does mostly the same thing, but he's actually fairly balance with lower damage scaling and a reliance on his team to follow him into battle(not to mention he can't grab someone from over a wall)

Nautilus doesn't have lower damage than Blitz. Naut was one of the highest damage jungle tanks before they found that his damage was so high, he can be played support and not lose much of it. If you don't focus Naut, his AOE will wreck your team.
It is true. Though if you dont care about ranked then normals is quite fun for me. I can play almost any champ and if i lose I don't get that disappointed. I have fun none the less.{{champion:35}}

only one champ hasnt been playing in the competitive scene over the last 2 seasons, that's darius.

So, hey guess what, games pretty balanced

It doesn't matter if a champion gets played, when their combined professional win-rate for the entire past 11 months across all regions is a big fat 0%

{{champion:37}}

Since when is having the 2nd lowest damage potential of all supports and being tied for lowest spell-base damage considered "oppressive?"  Or were you referring to the fact she has the weakest, most-expensive heal in the game?  Or any other of her weakpoints...  she doesn't actually possess strengths.  The patch 4.13 gutting made sure of that.

> [{quoted}](name=Gunpoint,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Mlrw0oEr,comment-id=001400000000,timestamp=2015-06-30T13:02:51.993+0000)
>
> She's oppressive as hell in Solo Queue, she doesn't need a buff. These champions need nerfs... {{champion:412}} {{champion:89}}  mabye even {{champion:40}}

I kinda agree with this, she is merely being overshadowed by the big three, she goes even with just about any other support.
